Fmla company is also a joke and HR has no idea what their doing because they have private companies do everything for them (tuition,fmla, benefits....) so of you have a question don't bother they won't know either lol and I just got this lovely letter in the mail stating their taking the hobby lobby way of thinking when it comes to women's health for their workers, meaning they are refusing to cover contraceptives (like they used to, which was 100% no questions asked) citing their religious "obligation". This company is sending me to school, once the contact is up I will be leaving asap and I will be faking and playing nice until then but please do not work here. I love my manager, she's a genuine person and all my managers have been great but they only let them do so much when changes need to be made. Oh and they'll send you to school for practically anything, however you sign a contact to work for them for a year and a half and they refuse to guarantee a position with your degree. They outsourced my future position a year into my program :) the most unchristian Christian organization ever. They fired/layed off hundreds of people in November 2022 but opened a new hospital and urgent cares in the area THEN needed people to work there....

review_title: Working with management is nothing but a brick wall and staffing is horrific
pros:
+ICU is all about teamwork. Seriously could not ask for a better set of coworkers, even the travelers. All amazing individuals who excel at their jobs.
+The benefits are decent, though I've been denied on health insurance claims for doctors that were in-network per the Anthem website. I also had a med that was repeatedly requesting prior authorization and Anthem couldn't be bothered to pick up the phone and let me know it was simply due to the wording of my doctor's script. I went almost a month without my migraine medications because of this and spent over 10 days in a row with a migraine before I finally gave up on waiting and called Anthem to sort it out. I had the med that same day, which is extremely frustrating as I could have had it fixed weeks prior had Anthem communicated the issue to myself or my pharmacy.
cons:
-Management does not care about you or your problems, even if you approach them multiple times asking for help to find a solution. 
-ICU RNs are constantly floated to other units. Unlike almost every other hospital in the state, Mercy Health - Springfield does not cap the number of patients an ICU nurse is given when floated to stepdown or med/surg. This means that an ICU nurse used to only 2-3 patients can be given upwards of 8 on a med/surg or observation unit. 
-At one point I was floated to a med/surg unit and 4/5 nurses assigned there that night were floated. 3/4 of the floated nurses were ICU. We were hired to ICU for a reason, not to be abused because the hospital is unable to appropriately staff the other units. I now spend anywhere from 1-2 shifts per pay period (up to a third of my work) being floated to other units.
-I was put through several extra classes in order to take on patients with a specific treatment need, such as Targeted Temperature Management and CRRT. It has now been 2 months since my last class and I have yet to be assigned any of these patients, despite there being a need on the unit. I have been told multiple times I am doing great as a nurse, so I have not been given any feedback as to why these patients are not being assigned to me, despite asking for this feedback and reiterating to charges that I can take these patients. Others that sat the same class as myself have been given these patients multiple times.
-I eventually applied to another healthcare system for PRN work as our unit was being called off on low census frequently. I was asked by that healthcare system if I would be interested in full time instead of PRN. I accepted and approached 2 different managers, the one for ICU and the one for the stepdown unit we frequently get floated to. While I was told on ICU there were no PRN positions available and that they were very sad to see me go, my followup message inquiring about PRN positions on other units was ignored. My first and only message to the manager of the stepdown unit was completely ignored. It seems that once you have decided to step down from full time, they are no longer interested in you at all.
-Apparently, there is a 4-week notice required in order to be eligible for rehire. This is the only hospital or health facility I have ever worked in with this requirement. As a result, I will be utilizing my PTO on my final week, since I only gave 3 weeks notice, which I thought was pretty generous considering I wanted to flip to PRN, not quit altogether. Apparently they aren't as sad to see me go as they claim to be. 
-Staffing is already completely atrocious with the exodus of several ICU travelers. Once staffing reaches a point that ICU cannot be floated quite as extensively, the rest of the hospital will suffer for it and staffing ratios will get completely out of control once again. 
-At the moment, they are pretty comfortable floating out half the ICU staff to other units in favor of regularly saddling ICU nurses, especially night shifters, with 3 true ICU patients apiece. There have also been multiple instances of giving a nurse with a CRRT patient more than one patient, which is negligent and irresponsible of management.

review_title: Best Job I've Ever Had, But Worried for the Future
pros:
* Excellent work/life balance, can work from home up to twice a week.
* Wonderful co-workers, we truly feel like we're a team and get along. Immediate management care for my well-being and professional growth.
* Great benefits and pay.
* Expansion means good job security.
cons:
* Have hours on call, usually not major but can interrupt my time off and makes me have to plan around social events.
* Insistence on budget cuts has forced us to use our personal devices for work purposes, without reimbursement. More cuts likely to come.
* Human Resource department is difficult to work with--conversations are usually one-sided.

pros:
This is no doubt that most autocratic organization I've ever worked at.    I had thought that organizations managed like this were only from bygone eras but the autocratic management style thrives at Mercy.

What does this mean? It means that it is centrally managed and trivial decisions are made at high levels.  Information and instructions are passed ONLY down.  NEVER upward.  Senior and mid level meetings consist of the most senior associate passing instructions to more junior associates.  Little or no discussion.  No back and forth.  

This is probably good for entry level people who want to learn quickly and have small salary requirements.   Management can quickly replace one junior engineer with another.
cons: If you want to work with senior and very smart people,  this is not the place.   Neither the salary nor culture provide any incentive to stay once you have reached a strong level of competency.

review_title: Registered Nurses Beware: This is not the job you're looking for.
pros: New facility, new equipment, new computers, nice rooms.
cons:
No breaks, poor compensation, poor management, knee-jerk reactive policies, overburdening nurses.

Horrible tracking of acuity; our med/surg floor was regularly assigned patients that should have been in stepdowns. We had constant rapid responses because of this, because asking a supervisor to move them never worked; they'd rather argue with you or tell you to convince the doctor for a transfer order. 

Breaks are never a guarantee, even lunch breaks. Only techs get guaranteed breaks, because they're part of a union. 

We would have to carry 6 patients with high acuities with no breaks, and then get in trouble if we had overtime, even incremental overtime. We were threatened with layoffs if the overtime didn't stop, so many nurses had to chart or do patient care off the clock in order to keep their jobs.

You have to travel with every patient that leaves the floor (Ie, xray, MRI, CT, stress test, etc) because even though our transporters are BLS certified, one time a patient coded during transport. This is just one example of the knee-jerk reactive policies put in place. When you have six patients, this sort of thing takes time away from your other patients, your ability to finish patient care and documentation, and puts everyone at risk.

Management will insist this is not the expectation to CTA. People are walking out on the job and leaving without other employment because of the workload and culture. Factory-like paper-pushers. Mercy pays their salaried employees $2.00/hour to be on-call for 24-48 hours at a time). Mercy should be reported to the department of labor.

pros: There were always an abundance of employees so work was pretty easy. They treated employees well with great long time benefits and annual raises.
cons: There seemed to be too many "bosses" . The nutrition department was split into many different areas with no real direction. they really hired about anybody and were bad at getting rid of workers who didn't "fit the bill" so to speak.

pros: Very smart people to work with. Certain Managers are really helpful. Can learn a lot and gain lots of experiences.
cons: The pay is some of the lowest in the area for hospital RNs. Expect way too much out of their staff in certain units with a "Don't Care" attitude from higher ups. Very little support staff in some units. Unable to use sick time when you are actually sick without jumping through hoops.

pros: Umm, no- maybe merging with Bon Secour will elevate them (?)
cons: As previous reviewers said, management expects a "culture of Jesus" that everyone is to adhere to while they lie, cheat, make false accusations against employees, verbally assault employees, talk unprofessionally behind manager's backs, collude to fire without cause, and act in ways that I simply could not believe I was witnessing.  If the CEO would hire some top-level, high-class executives who did not grow up here in Cincinnati maybe they could start building a professional, progressive culture.  I hope that Bon Secour comes in and fires them all- well deserved and good riddance.

review_title: Work atmosphere destroyed in less than a year by corporate
job_title: Computer Systems Analyst in Bridgewater, NJ
pros: I work with a lot of great people, but that is slowly changing as new corporate policies push good employees away.
cons:
Benefits keep getting worse. They love playing both sides of the Jesus coin. Won’t pay out PTO unless you give 20 work days notice when you leave. 80 page code of conduct policy that corporate itself violates. 

They announced a 1 billion dollar profit off of a company sale the same month they take away company phones and cut compensation in general. They told us that it extends the mission of Jesus. 

All good employees are leaving and not getting replaced. Increasing everyone else’s work load.  I could go on, but this depresses me

review_title: Catholic Healthcare Partners is a good place to work if you can handle the passive-agressive, political environment.
pros: CHP pays relatively well for the Cincinnati market. The facilities are nice and the equipment is excellent.
cons: For the most part, CHP hires from the outside for their director porsitions. As a result, don't expect much in the way of upward mobility, especially in certain departments. As a long-term employee, I and just about everyone else at my level knows that if we want to progress, we need to leave the organization.

pros: Decisions are made quickly and the organization can turn on a dime. Mercy is not afraid to take risks and often succeeds because they do. If you succeed in an environment of rapid change then this is the place for you.
cons: It's a very aggressive organization with considerable demands being placed on employees at the last minute. Often major change is accomplished through reactive measures. Does not value the role of IT significantly enough.

review_title: If you are a new nurse, DO NOT START HERE
pros:
Opportunity for growth
Several locations to choose from
cons:
Lowest paying for nurses
New grad residency requires a 3 yr work commitment and financial penalty if you leave from a company that is the lowest paying for nurses
Low PTO accrual
Wonky pay schedule (if you work nights the last Saturday of the pay period, everything after midnight goes on the next check)
Low raise %

pros: Opportunity for growth and development.  Employees dedicated to quality/safety, compassion/caring and efficiency/excellence. Many employees have been employed loyally for 20-30 years.
cons: Repetitive cycling (every 3-7 years) of leadership and executives; implement great "ideas/theory" prematurely in meetings without input/collaboration from "reality/practice". Processes and changes occur sometimes quicker than communication to those impacted. With the Magnet movement, greater collaboration with nurses.

review_title: Was great before Bon Secour "merger" December 2018
pros:
*Pay is good
*Coworkers
*Parking in garages
cons:
*No sick pay, only general PTO (I got 5.5 hours of PTO per biweekly paycheck)

*Retirement plan is a joke (.5% matching only up to 6%)

*Health benefits are worsening every year

*Human resource department is atrocious

*Departments are being consolidated from 3 local hospitals into one and are later cut. This is happening throughout the hospital system.

*Hard workers will be overworked, slackers are frequent and aren't punished, can call off consistently without consequence (not FMLA call offs)

*Management since Bon Secours bought out Mercy (was supposedly a merger but as a worker, we changed everything to be just like Bon Secours 

*I would have told everyone I know to apply here before Bon Secours bought out Mercy Health. In the past months with BS, the morale here has dropped considerably and upper management consistently makes rules that only make it worse.

pros:
a small hospital with less patients than some would expect. can be very slow for some positions or very busy for others. they offer school tuition reimbursement, but only for education that benefits the hospital. most positions are union. fewer employees creates better relationships. if you keep to yourself then you wont have any issues.
due to down time (for some departments) excellent place to work if working on education.
cons: management is lax at times, then strict on miniscule ideas. pay is low for secondary staff (i.e. non-nursing) facility is regularly understaffed. revolving door of employees in some departments. becoming to personal leads people into the social/work politics.

job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Cincinnati, OH
pros: My supervisor is always respectful, friendly and supportive. I receive training and knowledge everyday from my team and our supervisor. The pay is great and Mercy is a religious hospital that I enjoy working for.
cons: I can't think of many cons but if there had to be one, Mercy should implement a better career path system. I feel that the current system is cool to use but doesn't really point you in any direction when it comes to getting promotions or learning other jobs.

review_title: The best Non-Profit to work for in Cincinnati for 2013-2014
pros:
Great Benefits/ Especially for remote support
Good Pay
Good Management
Good Work Environment
cons: Since the company transitioned to a for-profit company, everything started going downhill quickly (Since 2015).  All of the once great perks and big team comradery within the company dried up.  Harsh and continual budget cuts have made work life difficult.  Moral consistently low.  Management forced to make painful and undesired cuts to labor.

job_title: Certified Surgical Technologist in Springfield, MO
pros: You gain experience and preferences of the doctors that work in our department.  You are so familiar working and knowing what they use for surgery their is no guessing what you will need for a scheduled case.
cons: Working in healthcare there are no special holidays that you get too close down for like other retail industries.  You go to work knowing it's 24 hours a day 7 days a week and you will be working your fair share of weekends and holidays.

pros: Good opportunity to learn.  Your coworkers are very helpful and willing to teach you.  You quickly become a project owner and learn how to manage projects and balance the different applications.  If you have no prior experience this is a good place for you.
cons:
You are not allowed to get comfortable there.  You are expected to throw yourself in and take on 50+ hours a week, right away.  Everyone is so busy and Mercy is so big it is hard to find time to meet with everyone.  Too many meetings.  They hire people right out of college so that they can pay them a low amount and they are willing to put in the 50 hours a week.  They do not like when you have to take off for kids.  Even if you haven't ever done it in the past.
The pay is a joke and when they expect you to work so many hours and they do not compensate for that in any way it is disappointing.  They give cost of living raises.   Typically the high performers get exactly what the low performers get.  Everyone comes in at a different salary.  Someone with no experience can be making more than someone with a lot of experience.  So if you work there for five years and you weren't promoted you could be making less than your peer that just started.

It is a very competitive environment and management likes it that way.  They will pin you against coworkers when evaluating the "numbers".  
As far as advancement you can only go as far as your team lead wants you to go.  Some team leads have employees that get promoted often and some team leads do not.  Although I don't think right now there are many positions higher than team lead.
The CEO has torn Mercy apart and made some really poor decisions along the way.  Only time will tell if they have actually worked.

review_title: Difficult environment to provide quality care.
pros: The co-workers are great, physicians are wonderful to work with, knowing your patients is an extraordinary experiance for both the patients and the employees.
cons: Employee satisfaction has hit an all time low. It used to be an excellent place to work.  Due to managerial changes it is no longer that. You can not provide qualtiy care that you would want for your loved ones when you constantly have to watch your back. Experienced employees are being terminated to save money by hiring younger employees. When a company terminates their experience there is no one to train the lesser experienced employees.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Defiance, OH
pros: Great coworkers and great doctors.  I feel that most people working here truly care about the patient.  There are always extra hours to pick up, and coworkers will cover for you if needed. Most nurse managers are great too.
cons: Pay is on the lower side.  A lot of "stuff" comes from Toledo who have no idea about the people working in our city (Defiance). What may work in bigger cities and hospitals may not always work in rural areas.

pros:
I like most of the people that I work with, they seem to be working for the right reason. 
There are decent benefits and there is a pretty big opportunity to get higher up into the company. 
They typically hire within the company, before hiring outside of the company.
Mercy wants you to use your PTO time!
cons:
The salary is a lot less due to being a non-profit company. 
There seems to be an issue with management currently, especially when it comes to annual reviews, someone has dropped the ball, however other coworkers have had no issues with their raises/reviews.

pros: Educated and compassionate individuals dedicated to understanding patients health and lifestyle on a more personal level with great follow up response in regards to a more stress free and manageable relationship in private healthcare diagnosis with accurate and successful results.
cons: Busy practice needs improvement with communication and, more hands on deck mainly with answering telephones and routine patient care.

job_title: IT Finance Analyst in Cleveland, OH
pros: Smart people and friendly.  Pay is pretty good however I don't have a good perspective since this was my first job as it pertains to my overall career goals.
cons: The company seems to be unstable and requires better standardization in order to provide stability.  I did not find it comfortable to work in the highly emotional business settings.

review_title: Like all jobs it has Pros and Cons.
pros: Love the people I worked with.  Liked working with the Physicians and NP's.  Nice working three days a week.  Befits are reasonable.  Yearly cost of living raises!
cons: In urgent care setting you are Required to work the Lab department with X-ray department, even though "Lab" is not what you went to school for.  If you make an error in the Lab department you loose your Lab & X-Ray job.  You are required to run both X-ray & Lab with you being the only one in both departments.

pros: It was a new unit so the working space was nice
cons:
It was a new unit and not all of the needed things were in place including a reliable attending physician and complete policies and procedures.
I was asked to do some really unethical things which is ultimately why I had to leave.
Nursing leadership is sorely lacking. Embarrassing really. Nurse managers tend toward defending the organization rather than supporting the staff.
Benefits are EXTREMELY limited and expensive.
I would rather die trying to get to another hospital than receive treatment at Mercy Health in Boardman/Youngstown/Warren Ohio

review_title: Not great, but not bad for recent college graduate.
pros: As everybody else mentions, basically all the benefits are nice. While I working, management was experimenting with flex-time, which allowed for you to basically create your own hours (as long as you worked 40 hours a week, and showed up between 7 and 9 AM every day). A very stable healthcare network that is expanding, so there is promise for more opportunities. There is hope for upward growth/promotions, but you have to be around for a while...
cons:
I was fresh out of a four-year college eager to learn, and develop some skills for my career. The job I thought I was getting was nothing I had imagined it to be. My work was very minimal, and management was reluctant to give me more work. I would finish before noon, and spend the rest of my twiddling my thumbs waiting for somebody else to ask for help. 

I could have been just the people I worked with, but the office setting was very quiet. Nobody talked, mingled, or even joked. Staring at a computer 8 hours a day can be taxing, it would have been nice if they encouraged a more energetic, playful work space. A coworker of mine was told she needed to settle down because management thought she was too "peppy." I understand the point of that, but at the same time, you try staring at a computer all day and find a way to stay sane. 

I felt very over-qualified for the work I was doing, which I was (high school diploma was the education requirement). the work I was doing was not challenging, and I wasn't really getting the skills I thought I would. 

I was getting paid $15 an hour, which was not worth it for me. Leaving the company and starting somewhere new was more inviting than sitting through a tough pay grade for a year, all for maybe a $5 pay bump?

pros: Some benefits are good such as the 403b. But not worth the stress. Meet a lot of really good people, but they eventually move on. A good I between job place.
cons: Teamwork is nonexsistance, especially with the carepath team. Everyone is trying to set you up for failure the majority of the time and leadership is the worst for making timely and pertinent decisions when it come to the welfare of their employees.

review_title: Enjoyed the job, not the pay.
pros: Great culture. The job duties and coworkers were wonderful. I loved getting out of bed knowing I was going to a job I enjoyed. Modern facility.
cons: Unfortunately, the pay is well under fair market value. I left to work at a hospital that pays about $10 more per hour.

review_title: Like a family, for better or worse.
pros: The Management staff tend to be understanding; your coworkers, even outside of your unit, start to feel like family; scheduling is pretty flexible, there are tons of opportunity to grow.
cons: Chronically unorganized and inefficient with any and all changes, lots of change for the sake of change, poor nurse to patient ratios hurt the whole team, administration can get hung up in insignificant details while turning a blind eye to the suggestions of its ground floor workers.

pros: benefits are decent, although the health. plan forces you to get all your services from the hospital - cannot use other facilities without a huge penalty
cons: some of the management staff are woefully ignorant on how to properly treat employees -- there's a sense of do whatever you need to do to get someone to toe the line

job_title: Certified Surgical Technologist in Paducah, KY
pros: Love taking care of the patient's and what used to be a close knit family of co-workers.
cons: Not trustworthy and not thankful for long time committed employees. The less work you do the more praise you seem to get. However the more work you do the more work they EXPECT from you because they KNOW they can COUNT on you.

pros: The staff was always kind
cons: They don't have a work life balance, you are there to fill there need and if you can't then they make it so you want to quit. The management is only out to better themselves and not take over any situation they will look bad in even if it's beyond your ability. They don't reward hard workers or anyone that goes above and beyond. You could be the best employee they ever had and do or need something that is inconvenient for the manager and they treat you like you should just quit

review_title: The B and C Team of Management
pros: Tuition reimbursement, insurance options ok, nice new corporate office building. That’s it- there’s a 20 word minimum in this field so just filling up space now.
cons: It’s a long list but unqualified, turtle paced executives top the list. Instead of firing large numbers of hard working employees, why not look to trim the rotting fat at the top. Your quality would improve as would your depressing culture. Worst health system I worked for in 30 years in 3 states. About 20 years behind the time.

job_title: Sterile Processing Technician in Cincinnati, OH
pros:
Excellent Benefits
Room for growth in different fields

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Toledo, OH

I'm just a receptionist, yes, but I overhear dozens of conversations from providers, managers and coworkers. Morale is down. Feel like a number. No longer a local health system but a cog in the wheel of a chain, with people making decisions who know nothing about our community.

job_title: Personal Care Associate in Youngstown, OH

cons: Short staffed at times, little to no help from certain nurses, some certain nurses treat you like a dog demanding things (where you'd need help) then they sit around most the time & expect you to do it on your own which is a safety concern or you go find another aide if lucky enough to have another on the floor with you.

pros: Co-workers are great.  Working overnight, staff really work as a team and are always willing to explain and teach new nurses.

job_title: Clinical/Clerical Medical Assistant in Paducah, KY

cons: Management constantly changing.  Employee happiness is not a concern. Not flexible with schedule.

review_title: Lots of potential. Little ability to capitalize it.

cons: Little to no work/life balance. Constantly swelling level of executive managers which change direction requiring the ability to constantly drop everything  until the next manager comes in and changes direction again. Executive managers do not value talent, experience, or education. Leadership of the physician group is what will ruin everything that makes Mercy unique.

pros: Merging with Bon Secours will hopefully increase the management pool for the better.

This is especially true of Ron Cherry.   HR is no help either and encourage management to lie.  BTW, Mercy Health tries to squelch the truth by forcing people who leave to sign a gag order.

review_title: nurses leave because they expect more

pros: At the Mercy health, I am a lifeguard and I have been very well treated there. I have found that I am always given time off it is needed and as long as i can find someone to cover my shift. I have also found that it is almost a family like experience to work along side them.
cons: I do not receive optimal pay for my position and at times feel pressured to work more than i think i should.

review_title: Good Place for Work/Care, But Needs Improvement

review_title: Loved working for Mercy Health, felt like part of a family

pros: Working with many different types of patient ,working with different patient from all areas will make it easier to be open to other needs

pros: Bonuses are offered when there is a need. Sometimes 200 every four hours on top of your pay.

pros: Working with the members of the health and wellness facility is very rewarding

The administration of the HealthPlex doesn't communicate very well with the staff and/or members.  This leaves the employees unsure of what the strategies are of the business.

Changes over the past 4 years leaves one to wonder if the facility will continue/become viable.

review_title: Inexcusable "issues" for being the largest healthcare system in Ohio - especially in 2014/2015...

pros: Comfortable work environment, nice staff

job_title: Front Desk Associate in Anderson, OH
